perturbation.explanation: Requiring notification only one month before expiration contradicts standard contract law principles and may be deemed unconscionable in many jurisdictions, as it doesn't provide sufficient time for the Network to find a replacement affiliate. Most states require a reasonable notification period for non-renewal, which is generally more than one month for agreements of this nature.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Unconscionability, Reasonable Notice

(d) Audit.
 
(i) During the Term and for one (1) month thereafter, Network shall maintain accurate and complete books and records in accordance
with generally accepted accounting principles and practices that shall contain sufficient information to enable an auditor to
verify, for the period under audit, Network’s Advertising Revenue, Network’s Transactional Revenue, the Affiliate Advertising
Share, the Affiliate Transactional Share and the accuracy of the amounts paid by Network to Affiliate hereunder, including under
Exhibit D (collectively, the “Revenue Share Records”). Upon not less than sixty (60) days’ prior written notice and not more than once every three calendar years, Affiliate shall have the right, at its sole cost and expense, during the Term and for one (1) month thereafter, to examine during normal business hours the books and records of Network for up to the prior calendar year and the then-current calendar year solely to the extent reasonably necessary to verify the Revenue Share Records.
perturbation.explanation: Limiting the audit period to only one month after the term and restricting audits to once every three years unreasonably restricts Affiliate's ability to verify revenue shares, which is contradictory to good faith and fair dealing implied in most commercial contracts. Many jurisdictions would view this as an unreasonable limitation on a party's right to ensure accurate accounting, potentially rendering the audit clause unenforceable. Additionally, changing the notification period to sixty (60) days may conflict with state laws governing audit rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing, State Laws on Audit Rights

The change could be argued as procedurally unconscionable, especially if the complexity of the audit requires more than 90 days for proper assessment.
